question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute the product
\[\frac{(1998^2 - 1996^2)(1998^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1998^2 - 0^2)}{(1997^2 - 1996^2)(1997^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1997^2 - 0^2)}.\]
ground_truth:
Applying difference of squares, we get
\begin{align*}
&\frac{(1998^2 - 1996^2)(1998^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1998^2 - 0^2)}{(1997^2 - 1996^2)(1997^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1997^2 - 0^2)} \\
&= \frac{(1998 + 1996)(1998 - 1996)(1998 + 1995)(1998 - 1995) \dotsm (1998 + 0)(1998 - 0)}{(1997 + 1996)(1997 - 1996)(1997 + 1995)(1997 - 1995) \dotsm (1997 - 0)(1997 + 0)} \\
&= \frac{3994 \cdot 2 \cdot 3996 \cdot 3 \dotsm 1998 \cdot 1998}{3993 \cdot 1 \cdot 3992 \cdot 2 \dotsm 1997 \cdot 1997}.
\end{align*}In the numerator, we get every number from 2 to 3994 as a factor, with 1998 appearing twice.  In the denominator, we get every number from 1 to 3993 as a factor, with 1997 appearing twice.  Thus, the fraction simplifies to
\[\frac{1998 \cdot 3994}{1997} = \boxed{3996}.\]

question:
We have
\begin{align*} &\frac{(1998^2 - 1996^2)(1998^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1998^2 - 0^2)}{(1997^2 - 1996^2)(1997^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1997^2 - 0^2)} \\ &= \frac{(1998-1996)(1998+1996)(1998-1995)(1998+1995)\dotsm(1998-0)(1998+0)}{(1997-1996)(1997+1996)(1997-1995)(1997+1995)\dotsm(1997-0)(1997+0)} \\ &= \frac{(2)(3994)(3)(3993)\dotsm(1998)(1998)}{(1)(3993)(2)(3992)\dotsm(1997)(1997)} \\ &= \frac{(2)(3994)(3)(3993)\dotsm(1998)(1998)}{(1)(3993)(2)(3992)\dotsm(1997)(1997)} \\ &= \frac{2\cdot 3 \cdot 4 \cdot \dots \cdot 1998}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot \dots \cdot 1997} \cdot \frac{3994 \cdot 3993 \cdot \dots \cdot 1998}{3993 \cdot 3992 \cdot \dots \cdot 1997} \\ &= \frac{2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 \cdot \dots \cdot 1998}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot \dots \cdot 1997} \cdot \frac{3994 \cdot 3993 \cdot \dots \cdot 1998}{3993 \cdot 3992 \cdot \dots \cdot 1997} \\ &= 1998 \cdot \frac{3994}{1} = \frac{1998 \times 3994}{1997} = \frac{(1997+1)(1997+1997)}{1997} \\ &= 1998 \cdot 1998 \cdot 1998 / 1997 = \frac{(1998)(1998)}{(1997)(1997)} = 1998 \cdot 2 = \frac{1998 \times 1998 \times 1997}{1997 \times 1997} = \frac{(1998) \times 3994}{(1)(3993)} = \frac{1998 \times 3994}{3993} \\ &= \frac{7988002}{1997} = \frac{(1998 \times 1998) \times \dotsm (1)}{1 \times 2 \times \dots \times (1997)} \times \frac{(3994) \times \dots \times (1)}{3993 \times 3992 \times \dots \times (1)} = \frac{1998 \times 1998}{1 \times 1} \\ &= 1998. \end{align*}
Final Answer: $\boxed{1998}$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
ground_truth:
Applying difference of squares, we get
\begin{align*}
&\frac{(1998^2 - 1996^2)(1998^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1998^2 - 0^2)}{(1997^2 - 1996^2)(1997^2 - 1995^2) \dotsm (1997^2 - 0^2)} \\
&= \frac{(1998 + 1996)(1998 - 1996)(1998 + 1995)(1998 - 1995) \dotsm (1998 + 0)(1998 - 0)}{(1997 + 1996)(1997 - 1996)(1997 + 1995)(1997 - 1995) \dotsm (1997 - 0)(1997 + 0)} \\
&= \frac{3994 \cdot 2 \cdot 3996 \cdot 3 \dotsm 1998 \cdot 1998}{3993 \cdot 1 \cdot 3992 \cdot 2 \dotsm 1997 \cdot 1997}.
\end{align*}In the numerator, we get every number from 2 to 3994 as a factor, with 1998 appearing twice.  In the denominator, we get every number from 1 to 3993 as a factor, with 1997 appearing twice.  Thus, the fraction simplifies to
\[\frac{1998 \cdot 3994}{1997} = \boxed{3996}.\]
